2022

Beyond charity: how asylum seekers in Hong Kong are weaving their way to empowerment
Subscribe to our YouTube channel for free here: https://sc.mp/subscribe-youtube Shirley Ballesberos came to Hong Kong from the Philippines in 1995 to work as a domestic helper to support her two young sons back home. After her contract was terminated in 2007, she tried to sue her employer and ended up seeking asylum after overstaying her visa.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=70S93OHpYJw

Learn about Hong Kong's asylum seekers at city's first Refugee Week
Hong Kong NGOs are organising a Refugee Week festival in hopes of connecting the public with the city's community of refugees and asylum seekers. From June 20 to 26, people are invited to an art exhibition, a film screening, a photography competition and other activities to learn about the 14,000 refugees and asylum seekers in Hong Kong.
https://www.scmp.com/yp/discover/news/hong-kong/article/3181636/first-refugee-week-hong-kong-educate-people-about-asylum
What's On: Around the World | Refugee Week
REFUGEE WEEK AUSTRALIA Refugee Week originated in Australia, where it has been running since 1986. Coordinated by Refugee Council of Australia. This year the festival shares the theme of 'Healing', and people are invited to take part by watching a film, reading a book or joining one of over 100 events across the country, including exhibitions, film screenings, food events, talks, walks and community celebrations.
https://refugeeweek.org.uk/whats-on-aroundtheworld-2022/
HKFP Guide: How to support Hong Kong's refugees, domestic workers & most vulnerable during Covid-19
Hong Kong's fifth wave of Covid-19 shows no signs of abating, with epidemiological modelling from the University of Hong Kong projecting the daily number of infections could peak at almost 183,000 in early- to mid-March. As case numbers rise, stories of how the pandemic has affected - and will continue to impact - the city's most vulnerable communities have emerged.
https://hongkongfp.com/2022/02/26/hkfp-guide-how-to-support-hong-kongs-refugees-domestic-workers-most-vulnerable-during-covid-19/
thehoneycombers.com
https://thehoneycombers.com/hong-kong/how-to-help-refugees-in-hong-kong/
How to Support the Charities Helping Hong Kong's Most Vulnerable During the Pandemic
The fifth wave in Hong Kong has affected a lot of people but more so for the city's most vulnerable-migrant workers, the elderly, refugees, animals and more. Here, we're letting you know the charities you can donate to and how you can help those affected by the pandemic.
https://www.tatlerasia.com/power-purpose/philanthropy/charities-donation-hong-kong-covid-19
COVID-19 Charity Initiatives To Support Now
With COVID-19 case numbers rapidly climbing and social distancing measures in full force, our hearts go out to the city's most vulnerable who must bear the brunt of the ongoing fifth wave. In light of the current situation, a number of local charities have launched appeals for donations and volunteers to support domestic helpers, refugees and other marginalised communities in Hong Kong through this challenging time.
https://www.sassyhongkong.com/support-covid-19-charity-lifestyle/

19 Refugee-Powered Culinary Programs - Food Tank
Culinary arts programs can equip participants with kitchen, hospitality, and business skills that individuals need for a successful career in food and beverage. These programs can be especially important for refugees and displaced persons who are trying to start new lives. More than 82 million have been forcibly displaced across the globe.
https://foodtank.com/news/2021/07/refugee-powered-culinary-programs/
The NGO helping to empower Hong Kong's refugee population
Filipino refugee Shirley Ballesberos has been trying her hardest to help refugees and homeless locals in Hong Kong - even though she and her 8-year-old daughter need the help as well. Ballesberos, 50, volunteers at Grassroots Future, a non-profit organisation that focuses on helping the city's asylum seekers through providing financial assistance and activities that give them new skills.
https://www.scmp.com/yp/discover/lifestyle/article/3143971/ngo-helping-empower-hong-kongs-refugee-population
Bonding Over Food: Hong Kong asylum seekers share their stories over home-cooked meals - Ariana Life
"Food is a universal language. It's how we express our feelings and love, and care for those around us." This is how LK*, an asylum seeker from Indonesia who has lived in Hong Kong for two decades, described the guiding principle behind the community storytelling project, Table of Two Cities.
https://www.arianalife.com/topics/refugees/table-of-two-cities-hong-kong-asylum-seekers-share-stories-food/

Tegan Smyth, A Finance Professional Who Decides to Address the Needs of Refugees Communities in HK
Many years ago, I met a young man who said that he wished he worked for a non-profit so he could empower many people. I told him that he did not need to work for a charity organization to do good. Many people do good things for the community while they are working for corporations.

Egyptian Recipes From A Table Of Two Cities Hong Kong
As Egyptian recipes go, this one is a local gem. These steamed cabbage rolls stuffed with a tomato-based, fragrant cumin and coriander seed sauce and rice make a delicious accompaniment to your meal. Serves eight.

2019

Art of Defiance: 6 refugees find purpose and passion - Ariana Life
In a small artist's studio on Lantau Island, floor-to-ceiling sculptures and vibrant canvases overrun the space. A drum set sits in one corner, barely visible under piles of animal prints and patterned textiles, while a needle perches mid-stitch on a hand bag in the centre of the room.
https://www.arianalife.com/topics/refugees/the-art-of-defiance/
Malagasy human trafficking victims seek refuge in Hong Kong - Ariana Life
Four years ago, a 22-year-old university graduate from Madagascar named Anna Rakoto* saw an online advertisement for a fashion retail job in Fuzhou, China, and eagerly applied. With guaranteed training, a decent salary, and potential connections to major international brands, it seemed like a dream.
https://www.arianalife.com/topics/refugees/breaking-the-chains-human-trafficking-victims-modern-slavery-hong-kong/

Lottery: A poem on the lack of compassion for refugees
"It is more convenient to blame you for daring to exist," writes Tegan Smyth, a poet based in Hong Kong This is a guest contribution for The Economist 's Open Future initiative, which aims to foster a global conversation on the challenges of the 21st century.

Clarisse Akonyi, a former nurse from Congo, has created a group that organises arts and crafts workshops for female refugees.

2018

'It's all about understanding': Refugees in Hong Kong dine together to mark World Refugee Day | Hong Kong Free Press HKFP
Refugee groups showcased their home cuisines in Wan Chai on Saturday to mark last week's World Refugee Day, featuring Sri Lankan, Egyptian, African and Togolese food. The event was organised by NGOs Table of Two Cities and BiteUnite, in collaboration with multiple grassroots initiatives including Taste of Hope Hong Kong and Art Women.
https://hongkongfp.com/2018/06/25/understanding-refugees-hong-kong-dine-together-mark-world-refugee-day/
Event: Mini Acts for the Greater Good brings artwork by refugees from around the world to Hong Kong | Hong Kong Free Press HKFP
Mini Acts for the Greater Good (MAGG) is holding an exhibition of over 100 diverse paintings and sketches by refugees who are awaiting asylum in Greece or Hong Kong. The upcoming event - called "Artists in Exile Near and Far: Refugee Stories Through Art in Hong Kong and Abroad" - is organised in collaboration with art [...]
https://hongkongfp.com/2018/10/01/event-mini-acts-greater-good-brings-artwork-refugees-around-world-hong-kong/

Delve further, however, and it becomes clear she is anything but. Socially minded, and tirelessly passionate, Smyth is the founder of Table of Two Cities, a...

Helping Hong Kong's Refugees Through Food - Hashtag Legend
Mahmoud fled persecution in Pakistan, arriving in Hong Kong in 2001. He had hoped to find a job and to make a future for himself and his wife. The couple's children were born and brought up in Hong Kong but Mahmoud remains a refugee. He is officially stateless and, unable to work, is unable to...
https://hashtaglegend.com/culture/helping-hong-kongs-refugees-through-food-table-two-cities-2017/
No play, no future: The bleak prospects for refugee children in Hong Kong | Hong Kong Free Press HKFP
Nino scans the form quickly, noting the phrases "class field trip" and "HK$50 fee". He puts a cross - no, my child will not be attending - before slipping the piece of paper back into his son's school bag. His son, Adam, is seven years old and his daughter Jenny is five.
https://hongkongfp.com/2017/06/18/no-play-no-future-bleak-prospects-refugee-children-hong-kong/
